text: [Music]
the great vin scully once said that
statistics are used very much like a
drunk uses a lamppost for support not
for illumination
when people look at statistics in the
NFL and especially surface level
statistics rarely are they ever gonna
form a new opinion based on those
numbers and if anything they're just
looking for the first numbers they can
find to vaguely support whatever opinion
they already had to begin with if they
like someone they're gonna naturally
look for stats to justify liking them
even more if they don't like someone
they're gonna hunt down every metric
they can find to justify that as well
statistics by their very nature are
misleading because the numbers
themselves are objective but the people
who use them are not and I can think of
no better example of that than a lot of
the media's reactions to this twenty
nineteen crop a first-round quarterback
so far this preseason every single day
has been a constant stream of hot take
after hot take talking about Kyler
Murray struggling with this Daniel jones
excelling at that and Dwayne Haskins
being well kind of all over the place
and with every one of those hot takes
comes some out of context statistics to
support them and frankly I'm tired of it
I'm tired of numbers being used to give
opinions instead of eyeballs and some
good old-fashioned critical thinking and
so today we're gonna do something about
it and set some record straight this
week I went through the first few
preseason games for the Cardinals
Redskins and Giants on a quest to
evaluate what Murray Haskins and Jones
have shown so far not from a pure
statistical perspective but from a film
perspective to give context to the
numbers and what I found was a much
different narrative than the one that
I've seen forming around this rookie
quarterback class throughout August when
you look at the surface stats it's
pretty clear that both efficiency wise
and production wise Daniel Jones is at
the best preseason of the group so far
in the first couple weeks he passed for
84% completions he got a couple nice
touchdown drives 12 yards per attempt
which is massive and an almost perfect
150 1.8 rating but when you look at the
tape and more importantly factor in one
extra very critical metric to the
equation that's being intentionally left
out that
narrative kind of pulls back
significantly average intended heir
yards is a number that is tracked by NFL
next-gen stats every season and it's one
of the few numbers that I've always felt
actually did a good job supporting raw
tape better than just completion
percentage and yards per attempt to at
least and what that number is is the
average number of yards that the ball
travels from the line of scrimmage to
the intended receiver
on a play the higher that number the
longer the average pass attempt from
that quarterback is which means on
average he's attempting more difficult
passes while a low number would indicate
that this quarterback rarely pushes the
ball down the field and really focuses
more on safer high percentage throws
underneath the coverage Daniel Jones
average intended heir yards this
preseason is just okay in the first
couple weeks it was only eight point two
seven and if he maintain that pace at a
much much larger sample size for say the
entire regular season that would put him
at 17th in the league right in between
Andy Dalton and Alex Smith which isn't
necessarily a bad thing mind you that's
just the style of quarterback that he
plays and it tends to make him very
statistically efficient within his
system meanwhile Dwayne Hoskins who was
criticized heavily after throwing a
couple of picks in his debut average
13.2 intended heir yards in that debut
and ten point nine the following week
which would have put him on pace for an
average of almost 12.1 over a full
season which would have led the league
by a mile
yes it's a small unsustainable sample
size just like Jones but that number
regardless of sample does a great job
illustrating the kinds of passes that
Haskins has been attempting and why his
small sample size of service level
numbers isn't really all that concerning
Cuyler Murray has a similar story he
looked quote-unquote accurate and
efficient in week one because his
average intended heir yards was less
than five which is incredibly short
while in week two he was taking several
shots down the field and nearly tripled
that average which predictably resulted
in worse efficiency the mistake that I
see people making the last few weeks is
that they latch on to one small sample
size of stats every single week to
support the opinion that they likely
already had
without considering the other samples
along with them that give more context
or considering the tape itself which
gives more context than anything else
let's use daniel Jones loan drive from
week one as an example which was pretty
much universally praised it was capped
off by a touchdown pass he went 5 for 5
for 67 yards and everyone said ok maybe
this kid is awesome after all but we
have to actually watch the tape to
understand how those numbers happened we
have to contextualize the difficulty of
the reads and throws that he was asked
to do on his first pass the Giants were
running a China concept some of their
teams call it India if you've heard that
before
against a single high man coverage look
from the Jets and on that shallow end
cut called a China route the corner was
sitting 8 yards off a little in cut
against a corner that's sitting way way
far off his man is basically just free
yardage which is why he threw it
immediately for an easy completion and
while yes I'll give him credit for
recognizing that Reid and delivering the
ball accurately and on time
that's not exactly a difficult throw to
make his second pass was on an RPO again
against man coverage where the Jets
showed seven against six in the box and
basically dictated the throw for Jones
and all it took was a little play-action
fake to get the linebackers flowing out
of the way and then he delivered another
quick accurate ball on the slant to take
and again I'm not knocking that he was
able to make a quick decision and
efficiently execute this play design I'm
just pointing out the relative ease of
the read and the throw that were asked
of him past number three was another
play-action clover concept from 21
personnel where Golden Tate was just
running the safety out of the way deep
while Latimer went underneath him on the
deep / route and this was against zone
coverage this time by the way so again
it was basically just stealing yardage
this play is open eight times out of ten
when you run it against zone and really
Jones's only read here after he checked
the position of the deep safety was this
flat corner when you read this concept
if the corner sinks back immediately off
the snap you'll know right away that
Latimer won't be open and you'll have to
move on likely to your check down in the
flat but if the corner gets stuck at a
shallow depth either because he sucked
up by the run fake or because he's
playing the running back in the flat
Latimer will pretty much always
be running wide open as you can see the
corner did get stuck in that flat as he
was playing the running back
Jones read that took a hitch to allow
Latimer to clear the linebackers and
then yet again he delivered another
accurate ball on time with great
mechanics we should give credit to Jones
here for executing this play to
perfection and by no means am i
advocating that Jones has not had a good
preseason thus far but to me the star of
the show is really the offensive design
itself and not the QB because patch
server is basically gift-wrapping throws
like this one to whoever his starting
quarterback may be whether it's Eli
Daniel or anyone else if I'm a Giants
fan I'm not excited about my
quarterbacks I'm excited about my coach
throw number four was another quick
decisive throw on a speed out against
off man coverage you may be sensing a
theme here and once again we see Jones
doing a good job of operating within
schirmer's framework of play design he
recognized coverage he made good
decisions and all those are good things
but where I give some pause is that
we're not seeing anything on these
throws that 90% of other quarterbacks in
the NFL can't do we're not seeing
anything new here to challenge what we
already thought of Jones after watching
him at Duke he got that so-called game
manager label as a prospect and so far
that's basically all he's done in the
preseason as well just manage the games
when it's crunch time or they're in the
red zone and he's got to make a
difficult throw against really good
defenders can he do that and elevate his
team above what they already are that
was the biggest question with him coming
out of college and that's why his fifth
and final throw against the Jets
concerned me just a little bit yes it
was a touchdown and that looks great on
the stat sheet but when you look at
where this touchdown pass was placed
honestly it wasn't good this was a cover
two zone look which was confirmed to
zone by the motion from the tight end
and luckily for Jones the Giants just so
happened to be calling a smash flat
concept here which is great against
cover to the flat route from the tight
end is supposed to freeze the corner and
place down low which means that Jones
gets to throw it up to a one-on-one -
Benny Fowler when he's all alone on an
island with the safety as long as you've
got a good jump ball receiver who can go
up and get it this is a really reliable
passing concept in the red zone which is
why most teams use it however Jones
didn't elevate the ball rule number one
of throwing this route as a quarterback
is to protect the ball you have to
either keep it high and at the back
pylon or high and outside the boundary
if you think your receiver can toe tap
it right on the paint but you never ever
want to drop it in to flat and to inside
because that's how you get undercut and
picked off this ball was way too low and
way too inside and he was
extraordinarily lucky that it was Santos
Ramirez and not Jamal Adams on the field
for this throw watch how Ramirez played
it because it wasn't all that bad at the
start he read the bend out to the pylon
well and drove on it and right there
he's already in position
even if he doesn't know it yet he
panicked obviously which just compounded
his mistakes later in the play but he
shouldn't have panicked because that's
right where he needed to be all he had
to do was just turn his head and the
ball was coming right to him he never
looked for it even when the ball was
whizzing right by his ear hole and
that's a frustrating missed opportunity
from a defenders perspective to not get
one of the easiest interceptions that a
DB could hope for was this Drive
successful for a rookie quarterback
debut yes were there some great things
shown by Jones like tight mechanics
quick decision-making and for the most
part good accuracy also yes but should
we only look at his stats on this Drive
and overlook that his touchdown pass was
not well placed at all and should have
been picked off in my opinion no
statistics do not give credit where
credit is due sometimes and they don't
give criticism where it's due either
stats overly criticized Wayne Haskins
for making literally the exact same
mistake that Jones just made when he was
picked off by Mack Wilson and side note
this actually was a good decision to
throw the rail route down the boundary
he just threw it in the absolute worst
possible spot just like Jones did but
stats don't criticize Jones at all
because he was just lucky enough to get
away with it both of their respective
quarterback coaches chewed them out for
the exact same mistake on Monday morning
I can guarantee you that and they also
probably showed them a million examples
of how not to make that mistake by just
putting drew brees on repeat in the
meeting room but in the media and online
somehow these identical mistakes are not
being seen as equal I mean to me this is
all very simple
quarterback's [ __ ] up they [ __ ] up a lot
sometimes they have head coaches that
plan for that and try to protect them
with easy reads and easy throws that
they don't get overwhelmed and sometimes
they completely take the leash off and
let them go out and make a bunch of
mistakes that they can learn from but
the only difference between the two
methods is how much crap or how much
praise these kids get in the media
honestly so far through two or three
games of this preseason for each
quarterback I've seen nothing that I
didn't already expect from back before
all three were drafted in April
Daniel Jones is a smart conservative
game manager type who could be maximized
by a good system and with a good play
collar and he can win a whole lot of
games that way Kyle Emery is an
incredibly exciting athlete and a very
pure thrower who's gonna take an
unbelievable amount of shots down the
field under Kliff Kingsbury and dwayne
Haskins is a tough-as-nails Ben
Roethlisberger clone who makes just as
many great pinpoint accurate throws as
Ben while also making some of the same
trademark inexcusably dumb throws that
Ben makes at least once or twice a game
to these guys to me at least are what we
thought they were and that's fine but to
let three weeks of preseason action
completely cloud or distort that just
because of some small sample size
statistical nonsense is just well it's
just that it's nonsense
two years ago DeSean Kaiser had arguably
the best preseason out of any of the
quarterbacks in his class while deshaun
Watson struggled a lot but by the end of
October Watson looked like a shoo-in for
Rookie of the Year and kaisers career as
a starter was already almost over I feel
like we all relearn this lesson every
year myself included that preseason is
basically meaningless and to not put any
stock into it at all
especially when it comes to quarterbacks
but here we are again having the same
argument again and I almost don't even
know what to do about it at this point
if you're watching this during the
preseason and you're a Giants Redskins
or Cardinals fan please take my advice
as a fan of a team that just went
through what you're all going through
right now and don't panic if your rookie
is a bad preseason game it happens
they're rookies they don't know what
they're doing yet and if they have a
great game that's cool too but a lot of
the time that just means their mistakes
were not punished as much as the other
guys don't put any stock in the stats
don't put any weight on what some
talking head says on TV 30 minutes after
the game is over and don't drive
yourself
crazy by constantly comparing your
rookie to every other team's rookies
trust me on that you'll develop a
complex from that [ __ ] real quick and
next thing you know you'll be drunk
shirtless and running down the streets
of Chicago screaming that Pat mahomes is
just a product of Andy Reid statistics
in the preseason
are entirely useless for analyzing
quarterbacks and they're almost entirely
useless for analyzing everybody else -
I'll never tell you not to watch because
let's be honest it's football and we're
all gonna watch because we love it but I
can tell you this to help you survive
every single August from here on out
don't get overly hyped don't get overly
angry and most of all please just don't
panic
[Music]
